posts._title: Benoît Jacquot – À jamais AKA Never Ever (2016)
posts.title: À jamais
posts.excerpt: Quote: A girl who is a body artist fall in love with a director. But the man had a traffic accident and dead. This film express the feeling of love and lose.

posts._title: Sultan Khodzhikov – Kyz-Zhibek AKA Lady Zhibek (1971)
posts.title: Kyz-Zhibek
posts.excerpt: Quote: Kyz-Zhibek – Kazakh poetic folk legend of the 16th century, tells about the period in the Kazakh nation when the people suffered from bloody feuds. In those times each province of the Kazakh nation had its own Khan and each tried to supersede the other. The love story of Tolegen, the brave warrior, and …

posts.title: Inca Light
posts.excerpt: Interpretive documentary in Peru featuring Machu Pichu. “Book-ended by the most awe-inspiring shots of the sky that I’ve literally ever seen, Fulton’s Inca Light might also serve as one of the most impressive ethnographic documents available.” – M Kitchell (letterboxd)

posts._title: Mani Kaul – Uski Roti AKA Our Daily Bread (1970)
posts.title: Uski Roti
posts.excerpt: SYNOPSIS From the back of the case: A desolate bus-stop on a highway… figure of a village woman – Balo, waiting to deliver a meal to Sucha Singh, the husband, a bus driver. He expects the traditional duties of an average Indian rural wife. Balo in turn accepts her husband’s independent lifestyle. Balo hurries to …

posts.title: Rodin
posts.excerpt: Quote: On the centenary of Auguste Rodin’s death, Jacques Doillon delivers a useful educational tool for the armchair traveler too lazy to go to a museum. Or read a book. “Rodin” could also be watched as prep work before going to the Musée Rodin, a partner in the film’s production. What it’s not so good …

posts.title: Tykho Moon
posts.excerpt: The McBee family has erected a government over a future ‘colony’, that looks like a run-down Paris divided into sectors by the Berlin Wall. All male family members suffer from a mysterious disease and are in urgent need of organ transplants. The perfect donor, Tykho Moon, probably has been killed in a fire, but according …

posts._title: Takashi Miike – Kaze ni tatsu raion AKA The Lion Standing in the Wind (2015)
posts.title: Kaze ni tatsu raion
posts.excerpt: (from Japanese Film Festival) Lion Standing in the Wind is based on a real story and chronicles the inspirational life of Dr Koichiro Shimada who sets off to Kenya to serve as a medical doctor. In a turn of events, he finds himself stationed in a hospital in Lokichogio in the heart of the Kenyan …
posts.titleEnglish: The Lion Standing in the Wind

posts._title: Andrew T. Betzer – Young Bodies Heal Quickly (2014)
posts.title: Young Bodies Heal Quickly
posts.excerpt: Quote: Young Bodies Heal Quickly, Andrew T. Betzer’s first feature after a storied career as a short film-maker, is about as personal as a narrative fiction can get: Betzer wrote, directed, produced, edited and even color-graded the film. But in this case, “personal” doesn’t mean a regurgitation of the filmmaker’s latest breakup or childhood ups …

posts._title: Khavn – Alipato: The Very Brief Life of an Ember (2016)
posts.title: Alipato: The Very Brief Life of an Ember
posts.excerpt: Synopsis A bunch of 10-year-old kids rob pedestrians and kill without mercy. But after a failed bank robbery, the dangerous game comes to an end with twenty years of imprisonment. After two decades, they are released but soon begin to disappear one by one.

posts.title: Upgrade
posts.excerpt: Quote: Set in the near-future, technology controls nearly all aspects of life. But when Grey, a self-identified technophobe, has his world turned upside down, his only hope for revenge is an experimental computer chip implant called Stem.
